description:
Did you leave your heart in San Francisco??

I knew I wanted to see this when I came to San Francisco!  This is such a whimsical piece of art designed by married couple, Claes Oldenburg & Coosje Van Bruggen!  I was fortunate enough to view three of their works of art in three cities in a span of three weeks without even realizing it until I looked up their other works!

You can find Cupid's Span along Embarcadero, in Rincon Park, just south of the Ferry Building.  It was installed in 2002.  The Bay Bridge is highly visible in the background.  Coosje van Bruggen decided she wanted the front of the bow downward and the feathers of the arrow in the air.  I read that the feathers really do move in the wind, how cool!  Coosje said it could also be interpreted as a tightened version of a suspension bridge, and that seemed to be perfect for the pair as they continued with their plans.  It is huge at roughly 60ft tall!  It is definitely visible from afar!

This sculpture is listed as one of the 15 Most Beautiful Places To Get Married in SF!  Not sure I would choose this place, but I guess others have!

It is worth having a look at and taking pictures.  I'm glad we could incorporate seeing this in our busy day of sightseeing with my friends!
author: Alana M.

description:
Cupid's Span is a fun location for a quick photo opportunity. I'd advise to go with someone to help you take those fun photos. I tried doing some selfies but couldn't get the right angles or get in the right position to take a fun shot. I looked like a weirdo out there trying to take some photos that didn't turn out to be posting worthy.

This gardening around this huge bow & arrow is well maintained. But if you get a bit closer to the bow & arrow itself, it needs a little love. I remember seeing something stuck at the top end of the bow, a balloon I think. And with the "friendly" seagulls, there's massive amounts of poop all over the figure.

It does add to the character of the area. A random, huge bow and arrow by the bay shore is pretty interesting. And as I mentioned early, photo worthy for your social media addiction.
author: Antonio L.

description:
Beautiful sculpture! Would recommend visiting if you're in town. It's right by the ocean too so you get a nice view whichever way you turn. 

There's a nice patch of grass underneath that people like to lay out and sun bathe on nice days. Most times you see lots of people strolling by along on the Embarcadero. People like to walk their dogs or just run down the Embarcadero in the fresh air. 

It's a beautiful spot to visit at any time of day, rain or shine. At nighttime there are lights from the ground that shine up and the bay bridge lights in the back as well.
author: Karina W.

description:
Cupid's Span is an adorable landmark in SF. I lived here for quite awhile without ever knowing it existed, but now I get to see it quite often and it never loses its charm.

It's located on a little green patch along the Embarcadero, so you can picnic beneath it, sit on the concrete nearby with a view of the water and the bow, or even bring your pooch to play.

It makes the skyline prettier - both in the foreground of the Bay Bridge and the city itself, depending on where you're looking at it from. It's also a fun little place to take visitors; everyone I've shown it to absolutely loved it. I'm really glad it's here :-)
author: Nic Z.

description:
Cool sculpture on the Embarcadero in SF

This was one I've bookmarked for some time and I've asked hubby how come I've never seen it yet and I've been to San Francisco many times. He looked at me and said we've driven by it a few times. Hmm...

When we finally parked at a metered parking right in front of it and preceded to head towards the Ferry Building was the only time I've seen it up close. Apparently I didn't know how big it was and frankly baffles me how I missed not seeing it. The huge sculpture depicted a Cupid's bow and was situated on a lawn with bay & city views. The backdrop was the Bay Bridge. It is a great spot for photo ops. People were relaxing on the grass enjoying the Bay views and some even waaay too relaxed as I could smell weed when I walked by a couple of young folks who were apparently enjoying smoking it. I'm not sure if Prop 64 includes smoking it in public. Meh, Bay Area pot laws are confusing to me.  

The sculpture was placed on a hill, where the arrow was sunk under the surface of plants and prairie grasses. So big and colorful that hubby had to cross the street to get a full view and get a good shot for me. The sculpture is the centerpiece of Rincon Park and it is on a nice spot. It's no wonder Cupid chose this very spot along the waterfront to shoot its arrow. Glad I finally got to see it.

Review #0926
author: May A.

description:
Did Cupid throw his bow and arrow into the ground because some wicked person broke his heart in San Francisco? Or did he too get hit by one of his love arrows and fall in love and run off with a gorgeous being and no longer needed to carry his bow & arrow? I don't know, but I do know if you are along the Embarcadero you should go see Cupids Span!

I love finding outdoor art sculptures. Cupids Span is a 60ft sculpture that was commissioned by GAP founders Donald & Doris Fisher and created by Claes Oldenburg & Coosje van Bruggen and is in Rincon Park along the Embarcadero.  It's kind of hard not to miss.

Both sides of Cupids Span offers get views, either the bay bridge or the city view.  Check out it, take some pics, and speculate why Cupid doesn't need his bow and arrow anymore haha. 

Another fun find in the city!
author: Monica O.

description:
A beautiful sculpture along The Embarcardero, so cute for relaxing at a mini park, taking a walk, jog or run, or maybe playing Pokemon Go and taking a selfie with a pokemon.
This is an adorable landmark at The Embarcadero.
author: Jade M.

description:
I've been to the city so many times and even lived 30 minutes away from SF years ago! But everytime I come to SF there is always something new and beautiful to see! SF always seems to amaze me! Cupid's Span has been one of my "need to go" to list and Im glad I was able to see it! 

It surely is humongous so you wont miss it! Its located on Rincon Park on Embarcadero close to the Pier. Definitely a great place for photo ops with your love one. It also has a place where you can sit and have a picnic and just stroll around the area.

As for parking we got lucky that we found a metered spot right in front of it. As you know its always hard to find parking in the city so you may have to walk a few blocks to get to the park! Definitely a must see when you are in town!!
author: Charmaine D.

description:
C entered around romantic nostalgia
U nique bow and arrow design
P ublic art for us to enjoy
I n Rincon Park on the Embarcadero
D esigned by Claes Oldenburg and Coosje Van Bruggen
S an Francisco is a place where we left our heart

S culpture made of fiberglass and steel
P ort land
A view of the San Francisco Bay, Bay Bridge and beyond. 
N oteworthy place to celebrate an anniversary

#CupidsSpan
#SanFrancisco
#WeddingAnniversary2016
author: Elle N.

description:
This is an intriguing landmark in San Francisco.
We came upon this place as we were walking along the waterway. It sits on a small grassy hill, with people relaxing around it. It proved to be a good photo, with the buildings in the background and the sun sitting just behind it.
This monument was an interesting find also because it was the weekend before Valentine's Day. So anyone looking to make a good statement come next Valentine's Day, check this place out!
author: William G.

description:
I had seen Cupid's Span somewhere online. So I wanted to go see it next time I was in San Francisco since it's a great photo op. We stopped by around 8pm on a weekday and parking was very easy to find. We walked around for about an hour and even walked towards the Ferry building

The Cupid Bow didn't have anyone sitting in it or around it which made for perfect photo opportunities. The grass was nice and well made maintained. There were a lot of people walking around on a nice summer day. There are also a lot of homeless people walking around the park talking to themselves.

I loved this outdoor piece and it was very beautiful to look at and photograph. You should look at it if you're ever in San Francisco and stop by in the middle of the week during the evening.
author: Karen C.

description:
Fell in love at first sight!
I first saw this in a movie, Play it Cool, and I thought it was magnificient. On a recent trip to SF, I did not think there would be time. As luck would have it, my husband carved out some time to visit Cupid's Span. We had gone to the ferry building to get some grub, and we ate it in front of the "bow and arrow." It was a marvelous sculpture, and we felt the romance. I hope to visit again to be struck by its beauty.
author: Leanne R.

description: This installation at the park is so much fun.  I know it doesn't necessarily look like much but this spot will forever bring back fond memories of my time spent here with my lil family.  My baby girl had just started walking and she did so here as well as the day before at the Monterey Bay Aquarium.  Parking was tricky but we luckily found a spot across the street.  We stayed a while and walked up the block to where they looked like they were having a farmer's market.  That was fun. There were a lot of people here taking photos.  Of course this was a popular spot on Valentine's Day!  This is easily something that you could just drive by but you may as well get out and stretch your legs a bit. It was a nice day.  I'm glad we were able to stop by for a bit.  I'd definitely stop here again, maybe have some lunch out on the grass next time.  This was the perfect photo op since we were in the area on Valentine's Day!!
author: Chris C.

description: Very quiet and peaceful place. I often go there after my studies. Here you can relax and read a book. Also here is a very beautiful view of the Bay.
author: Sofya K.

description: Romantical... I love the unique 60-foot sculpture installed along the Embarcadero. Great photo op with the Bay Bridge in the background. Will need to come back at night to see the bridge lighted up. It's a nice place to take a leisurely walk next to the waterfront.
author: Helen H.

description:
"I left my heart in San Francisco.
High on a hill it calls to me...
To be where little cable cars 
climb halfway to the stars!
The morning fog may chill the air,
I don't care! 
My love waits there in San Francisco,
above the blue and windy sea.
When I come home to you, San Francisco,
your golden sun will shine for me!"              --Tony Bennett 

This is a very cool sculpture at the Embarcadero!

Made of fiberglass and steel, this 60 feet tall structure is about 140 feet wide.  
Presented in November 2002 by the married team of Swedish sculptors, Claes Oldenburg and Coosje vanBruggen, it is part of an ongoing effort to beautify the City of San Francisco!  The artists also have famous pieces in Tokyo, Milan, and Minneapolis.

The positioning of the sculpture suggests the shapes of a ship to some people and possibly a suspension bridge to others.  It is designed to inspire conversation and stimulate the imagination!

The title of this masterpiece is in reference to Eros, the Greek god, also known as the Roman Cupid who shoots arrows into victims.  The blunt tipped lead arrows evoked feelings of aversion - the opposite effect of the sharp golden arrows which resulted in strong attraction between the targeted humans.  Yes, Cupid is a bit of a rascal!

Donated by Donald and Doris Fisher, the founders of Gap Inc., Cupid's Span seems to be in a very appropriate place - especially since Tony Bennett sang, "I Left My Heart In San Francisco"...
author: Nadine C.

description:
beautiful Bay view whether day or night.  it can be a little sketch at night, but that's expected.  nice walk along the embarcadero.

the bridge lights are a site to behold.  go at night, you won't be disappointed.
author: Roger K.

description: I have been eyeing this for a while now. It's a great statue and really cool for pics, but there isn't much there after 5 pictures, which is why I only gave it 4 stars. If you are in the area, then swing by. If not, it's not worth a trip.
author: Crystal Y.

description:
Super pretty and with the bay bridge back drop you cant go wrong!
Worth the extra three minute walk from the ferry building.
author: Ella A.

description:
Massive yet beautiful monument; reflective of love, San Francisco and all its glory.

Sits near Pier 1 and offers an amazing view of the Bay, Golden Gate Bridge and Fisherman's Wharf area.

Indicative of the famous saying "I left my heart in San Francisco." A must see when visiting the beautiful city of SF.
author: Christy A.

description:
As Vicky and I drove into San Francisco, I spotted this awesome Claes Oldenburg sculpture and then I talked Vicky & Dorothy into wandering back after dinner so I could take pictures. 

I love Oldenburg scultpures...the typewriter eraser in DC, the safetypin in NOLA, the trowel in Grand Rapids...LOVE. So discovering a new piece of his unexpectedly was great.

The garden around the sculpture is lovely and the space next to the bay is great. We were there at night but there were lots of people milling about so it still felt safe.
author: Jen L.

description: I work in the financial district very close to Cupid' Span so I usually come out here to eat lunch with my coworkers every once a week or so! Love this place and all the views it overlooks just from sitting in front of this art piece.
author: Amy L.

description:
When artists Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen were commissioned to construct an art piece on Rincon Park along Embarcadero in 2002, they couldn't have picked a better pair of artists. 

If you're not familiar about their work, they typically make giants sculptors out of mundane objects like the Spoonbridge and Cherry http://mspmag.com/getattachment/Out-And-About/Articles/Museums-And-Galleries/The-Cherry-on-Top/0913_cherryontop_p01.jpg.aspx in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Shuttlecocks http://queerty-prodweb.s3.amazonaws.com/wp/docs/2014/10/cocks.jpg in Kansas City, Missouri and Plantoir http://jschumacher.typepad.com/.a/6a00d8341c339953ef0133f4eb3a6f970b-800wi in Des Moines, Iowa and other various location in Europe, Asia and North America. 

According to the artists, their inspiration for Cupid's Span was the home port of Eros. I don't know if the first thing that comes to mind is Eros when mentioning San Francisco as that should be Las Vegas, IMHO. I can see if this was The Castro and it would make perfect sense, but I still like the piece, regardless. The first rendition of the sculpture had the arrow pointing towards the sky, but they had structural challenges so they decided to point it downwards and making the feathers as the focal point. 

The object of an art piece is to evoke an emotion - whether good or bad, it's very subjective and open to interpretation to the individual. You either like it or you don't, and you surely can't please everyone. I happen to like it as it blends quite well and also stands out within the surrounding location. You can also view it from different angles, backgrounds and different perspective at different times and gives you something different every time. 

I also find it appropriate that it's pointing down towards the heart of San Francisco, where many people have left theirs.
author: John G.

description:
Beautiful views of the bay! My friends and I were lucky it was a bright and sunny day when we visited Cupid's Span. Thanks to fellow Yelper Giovanna R.'s photos from last week, I was determined to make this the first stop in SF when celebrating a friend's birthday. When we arrived, some kids had climbed up the bottom half of the bow (quite a feat, I probably wouldn't be able to do that) but luckily, their parents convinced them to go before we started taking photos. This place is great for taking wedding party photos, as we saw one having a photo shoot, thankfully after capturing our own selfie stick powered shots haha. Bring your selfie stick! We saw others with them too so don't get discouraged.

The whole bay is visible and there aren't too many tourists if you get there by noon. I went on a Saturday and the area wasn't as crowded as I thought. Some go jogging, walk their dogs, take photos, etc. Bring the family and some friends! It's really a refreshing change compared to the usual Pier 39 where you'll get sucked into pricey tourist traps. We walked down toward Pier 39 and along the way we passed by the Ferry Marketplace with a Farmer's Market! You can't miss the white tents! There's metered parking along the Embarcadero. Try to get there early for a close spot.

Artwork and bay views that take your breath away. I'll be back with family in tow.
author: Kristine F.

description: Absolutely beautiful!!  My friend who got married in San Fran. specifically wanted to get photos by Cupid's Span so we made it happen. It is huge and rather breath-taking. The fact that it is on the water makes for even better photos and scenery in general. You do have to park on the street to get to it, however, we were able to get a parking spot so it worked out. Definitely something great to see in person if you're in the area!
author: Ashley D.

description:
I find it really interesting how there could be close to 100 reviews for a sculpture (not too famous I suppose) in San Francisco. Well nevertheless, here I am, adding my addition to this collection of reviews. 

I'm personally a big fan of art, and I love this little area of Cupid's Span. It's really colourful, right by the waters of the Embarcadero. Even though I visited this sculpture and thought it was beautiful as it had a bit of greenery and flowers  right beneath it, I had no idea what it was until I'm writing this review. 

Apparently, Cupid's Span was built in 2002. The curve of the bow represents a boat and the lines of the bow and arrow is reflective of the Bay Bridge at the back.
author: Kristy N.

description:
Cupid's Span is a fun sculpture along the Embarcadero near the Bay Bridge. It's probably a nice place to be if you're in love; it seems like a great place to take engagement photos.

For Benji, it's just another nice spot to sniff around and meet strangers. According to him, everyone there is very friendly and are willing to pet him.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Cute hangout spot! I enjoyed the view there. Good view of the bridge, islands, and the bay. Came here a few times during my lunch, there were quite a few people but still able to find a place to sit. Enjoy the sun, breeze, and fresh air. Take some selfies while you're at it! 

PS for Pokemon Go'ers: It's a gym and there are plenty of pokestops around. Happy hunting!
author: Benita M.

description: Decided to be tourists for a day and came to visit this spot with the baby. The baby was sleeping when we got here but she eventually woke up. The weather was a little too hot but we had a great view of the Bay Bridge. Definitely one of the many places that I always wanted to check out and finally got to check this off my list.
author: S L.

description: To me, this is the coolest symbol of love from the artists to the city of San Francisco. I just my walking there during lunch time, just observing people while lying on the grass. I also like to bring my sketchbooks and colors and get inspired. I don't see the dislike of this beautiful sculpture, is fun, is colorful, is very San Franciscan. And yes, I am so tempted to climb it as many of you!
author: Carmen V.

description: This spot offers beautiful skyline views and ocean views.  If you're a sucker for good views this is it!  There's a grassy area beneath the span where you can come have a nice picnic or just enjoy the spectacular sights!
author: Laura L.

description: I walk a dog here twice a week and definitely recommend it as one of the better grassy spots that's far away enough from the street, always clean and frequented by mainly calm and sweet dogs. A lot of people working in nearby buildings bring their dogs to work and so lunchtime is pretty busy in this area, so I would recommend walking your dog here earlier inn the morning or after lunch and before rush hour. Prefer this area over the enclosed Rincon Park on Beale Street as that park has zero shade or grass. Unless of course, you prefer an enclosed area.
author: Kristina B.

description: This is a pretty cool photo spot if you're into that. The bow and arrow are pretty big and super nice and well kept. The garden around it is neat. Great view of the waterfront and the bay bridge.
author: Juan F.

description: I often review certain buildings or landmarks as good for a photo opp and move on.  This is one of them.  After you visit the Ferry Building, continue along the Embarcadero towards the Bay Bridge and you'll end up in Rincon Park where it is.  Try to arrange the shot so it looks like the arrow is shooting you in the butt, it's funny.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Isn't it romantic? 

The arrow is embedded in San Francisco overlooking the Bay Bridge, Treasure Island and the Easy Bay. It's kind of a romantic city gesture, X marking the spot where Cupid hit and now a little landmark and part of the city. 

Makes for an excellent stop off on one of my favorite walking trails in San Francisco, the Embarcadero. I love the water and views.
author: Rebekah T.

description: If you are looking for cute doggies to play with there seems to be an abundance of little dogs all over the Cupid's Span lawn area. Convenient spot to take a stroll by the water. Easy access to Muni trains. Plenty of food options with the Ferry Building and cafes nearby. Perfect view of the Bay Bridge any time of the day.
author: Yad L.

description: One of the best places to be close to the water this side of San Francisco. Great place to people watch.. or dog watch if thats your thing.
author: Justin S.

description:
LVOE oops i meant LOVE..... hint hint... Louis Vuitton..... wink ^.*

Every time i drive by here i tell myself i should come here for a photo shoot. one day i finally got the time to stop by and take a nice pic. It was a like a big deal to me because when i am in the city i am on the go and have a busy schedule ahead of me but instead i made time for this. which was well worth the time.

 I really enjoy my time here just taking selfies and such ha. Another thing on my to do list is to climb to the top of the bow and take an amazing shot. Unfortunately that day i was in dress shoes and it was going to happen. 

I am not even sure if we can do that, but i think i should start training on my hops. I am not sure if this action is illegal but sometimes when i drive by i see people running up to the top of the bow like ninja warriors. lol ....i just love the vibe of this statue, it is so iconic in SF to me, its like the perfect spot for many things. 

Pro

- It has a nice view such as a nice back drop to this statue,
1. there is a bridge, water, 
or 
2. you can stand the other side of the bow and arrow and get the SF city back drop. 

- Its a very cute and romantic statue, great for a meeting place and have your first date here. lol ....just bring some coffee here and chat it up. 

- This is the perfect place to just take a picture for valentines card. 

- this statue is around the nice area, where there are lots of yummy restaurants available for your to enjoy. Sit back at a nearby restaurant and enjoy the view. 

- great location to do your exercise such a nice jog or  run along the pier. 

Con 

- the only con i can think of would be the parking. But who drives in SF once you find a parking spot. it is Easy to find and accessible by walking or muni around the city.
author: Alex T.

description:
How do you review a landmark?  How do you give a landmark a bad rating?
Cupids span is as much a part of the SF skyline as is any skyscraper.  It's one of those iconic images that all locals know and usually take for granted.
It's a beautiful site and stirs images of love and romance in everyone that's is in its pressence.  

Even on these rainy sf days I can look at it and things don't seem so gloomy.
author: Ronny M.

description:
Ahhhh sweet love. The only emotion that creates such magic. When lovers gaze into each others' eyes, their hearts synchronize. Falling in love creates effects like that of cocaine. Cherished cuddling can release endorphins. Even when looking at a picture of a loved one, it can actually relieve pain. And when absolutely committed to love, it is more than just a vow; it's a promise.

If this location doesn't symbolize romance in the slightest, then I don't know what will.

Even Sam Cooke had to sing for himself, "Cupid, draw back your bowwwwwww."

There's nothing sweeter than being in love and knowing that you ARE indeed loved. 

This is a very beautiful stretch of Embarcadero with great views of the Bay Bridge, Treasure Island, the Ferry Building, Financial District, and even the boats and ferries that pass along these bay waters. 

A perfect backdrop for romantic pictures, marriage proposals, or simply asking the other, "Will you be mine?"

As a true romantic at heart, I can appreciate the sentiment behind this sculptural artistry. 

So for those of you who are smitten by that special someone, this place will definitely heighten those feelings of being in love.

Caution: Hotel stay in this area is very expensive so if you wanna catch a room afterwards for a good deal, make sure you're willing to catch the MUNI, BART, or able to drive further into a cheaper area in the city. 

You know, since you're in that romantic mood and all.

Love may be free, but it ain't always cheap. Fo realllll doe!
author: Ann S.

description:
More art! I love how much art is all around San Francisco. I have been to this city a few times when I was younger, but now that I am older I can appreciate the artistic nature of this beautiful city. This another strange artistic landmark in the city, and one of those cool little "romantic" type things. 

Yet, another one of those little things that you should see when you are in the area.
author: Tina S.

description:
More commonly known as the "bow and arrow" and located in Rincon Park. It was commissioned by Donald and Doris Fisher (founders of Gap, Inc.) and donated to the City of San Francisco. It's a really stunning sculpture and looks absolutely gorgeous with both backdrops: the Bay Bridge and the buildings across The Embarcadero.

We visited on a particularly nice day with beautiful skies. It was also not busy or crowded, which made it easier to take photographs. It would have been a perfect experience, had it not been for the guy sleeping in front of the sculpture (seriously, the entire grassy hill was vacant and he chose the spot right in front of it) and the tourists idiotically and unsuccessfully climbing on the bow. I don't understand why people think it's okay to climb on sculptures.

More fun facts: Since San Francisco has the reputation as the "home port of Eros," artists Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen decided to use Cupid's bow and arrow and created it to look like it was shot into the earth. It is made of stainless steel, structural carbon steel, fiber-reinforced plastic, cast epoxy, and polyvinyl chloride foam; then painted with polyester gelcoat. Dimensions: 64 ft. x 143 ft. 9 in. x 17 ft. 3/8 in.
author: Amelinda L.

description: Awesome place to sit and just watch. The views are amazing. Our kids enjoyed rolling down the grass hill.
author: Dominica R.

description:
This is a pretty cool touristy spot if you're around the pier! It's at the very end of the pier so I do suggest you driving down the street. There are also parking on the street on the side of the Cupid's Span and also across the street. Be sure to have coins and I think the meter did have the credit/debit card insert.

It's kind of a small place and the only thing you really see is the Cupid's Span (the arrow) and the Bay Bridge. It's something really special, in my opinion. It's just a really cool art work/landmark out here in San Francisco. You also see a lot of joggers and other San Franciscans around as well. It's also pretty close to the Ferry Building, so you can grab a bite or coffee and take a stroll down the street! 

It's just a lovely place to come visit, probably with your loved ones! You can't go wrong with spending time here taking in the SF breeze by the Cupid's Span on your date ;)
author: Wendy Y.

description:
Right off the Bay Bridge, is this huge structure.

It is gorgeous at night and the place to take pictures of Bay Bridge as well as this Span. 

Parking is along the road and depending on time of day and what day, it can be either tough or easy to find. 

Everyone is always tempted to try and climb the lower half and many do.
author: Roger A.

description: Wanted to take a picture here for so long. Finally I took Moon Le here and we had a good time at the park. She enjoyed the weather and view, also dogs were playing and she got to play with them. Pictures with the bow and arrow came out really nice!
author: San B.

description: Parking was very hard to find, especially during the weekends.  Found parking on the street.  What a cute place to take pictures!!!  Be sure to put this on your "to do" list, especially if you're a tourist like me!
author: Yuka N.

description: Couldn't skip up the opportunity for a photo op.. even if parking was horrendous. Located walking distance from the Ferry Building, we JUST HAD TO stop by to take a few photos before our next stop. Definitely bring a pair of wide angle or fisheye lens since it's hard to get the whole bow in a photo unless you're super far away!
author: Jennifer W.

description: This is quite a piece of artwork!!! I hear that it has something to do with the song I left my heart in San Francisco, but I can't be certain. It's a great sculpture and very imaginative. It's in a nice area on the Embarcadero also. A nice place to stop by!
author: Sandra P.

description: It's a sculpture of a giant bow and arrow that's stuck in the ground. For those of you who don't appreciate art, it might sound boring but it's not. It's a cool sculpture and if you're visiting from out of town, you should come and check it out. You can also get some great photos of the Bay Bridge here.
author: Anna F.

description:
I live a couple blocks from here, so maybe I'm just sick of it, but it just doesn't really do it for me. 

It looks cool from a boat or at the end of a pier aka it looks good from far away (like a Monet), but up close, it's just kind of tacky.  I don't typically write reviews about this sort of thing, but does it not bother anyone else that the bow is stuck in the ground?  It makes sense for the arrow to be stuck after it's been shot...

Anyway aside from that, it's fun to climb.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Coosje van Bruggen and Claes Oldenburg created the infamous sculpture called Cupid's Span through the commission of the founders of Gap, Donald and Doris Fisher, with the intention of connecting the sea and land to an intangible form called love. To them, it was inspired by San Francisco, known as the city of love and sexual freedom personified by the Greek God Eros and the love between the married artists.  Due to the location of the sculpture, passengers can view it from the Bay Bridge when driving, and it is easily accessible from the Embarcadero BART Station. It's in a location that profits the GAP headquarters as well as the BART community.

Many synthetic materials were used to create Cupid's Span, located at Rincon Park. The two artists had used vinylester resin, E-Glass, PVC core, steel armatures for the shape, and two types of gel coats. Van Bruggen and Oldenburg were influenced by the idea and theme of love Since San Francisco is the city of sexual freedom, they used the form of Cupid's weapons to recreate the physical manifestation of Eros. The colors of the entire sculpture are very saturated and warm. The bow is a warm tanned brown color, while the shaft is colored as stainless steel. The fletching is probably the most distinct part of the sculpture for the very distinctive saturated red color. The red tip of the fletching is the symbol of love, while the arrow, being at a diagonal view towards the ground, symbolizes fertility. The surrounding nature is healthy and Cupid's Span emphasizes fertility, love for the community, and finding love within the city.

It is important to understand the intentions of Oldenburg and van Bruggen, which were that their idea of love has been manifested into their sculpture. They also wanted to show how fertile the land is and to give back to the earth. They made the sculpture pointed downwards towards a small puddle of lush green grass in Rincon Park, adjacent to the GAP Headquarters, instead of being right side up with the arrow pointing towards the sky. According to van Bruggen and Oldenburg, their intention was to create a sculpture that symbolized "romantic nostalgia" due to the rich history of sexual freedom in San Francisco.  Both couples had been married for a long time, so the sculpture symbolizes the marriage of the Fishers as well as the married artists themselves.

When writing about the relationship between the accessibility of public space, art, and money, Boris Groys's article called "Art and Money", states, "... art installation ... builds a community of spectators precisely because of the holistic, unifying character of the space produced by the installation. The true visitor of the installation is not an isolated individual, but a collective of visitors."  By placing Cupid's Span adjacent to the Gap building, the headquarters is able to take advantage of visitors and market their brands, Gap Inc., Banana Republic, and Old Navy, to those who do not know the fashionable brand. By marketing brands, this ties in with David Harvey's "Right to the City" article which states, "the quality of urban life has become a commodity for those with money, as has the city itself in a world where consumerism, tourism, cultural and knowledge-based industries have become major aspects of urban political economy."  The Fishers are able to take advantage of promotions by creating a public space where any social class can gather. Janna Malamud Smith's article "the Importance of Public Space in a Fractured World" states, "...the poorest visitors and the richest to have the same sense of belonging."  Tourists and locals are able to visit the sculpture, admire it while taking pictures, and provide their personal opinions about the value of the sculpture. 

When I observed the sculpture, my first opinion was that it was really clean and well-maintained. The grass and shrubbery were well-nurtured and there was not a single piece of trash to be seen, despite the abundance of visitors. I interviewed several people who were walking around the park with their kids, or taking photographs, about their opinion on the sculpture. According to a couple who had paused to take pictures, they said the sculpture was a symbol of love. Another person said it was an ugly piece that did not fit with the environment and blocked the view of the majestic buildings behind it. Another keen observer said it looked like a ship on land, due to the way the bow and shaft were angled. To that observer, it depicted an outline of a ship with a vertical mast with no sail. In my opinion, I now see that resemblance, but only after that observer pointed it out and I found it quite fitting since it does overlook the San Francisco Bay.

The theme of love is said to emerge from Cupid's Span, a sculpture commissioned by the GAP founders, the Fisher family. Both the artists, Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen were able to take the theme further to create a physical embodiment of fertility, freedom.
author: Theresa C.

description: You must visit and take a snap! With the water front view and Bay Bridge, you hit three photos ops in one stop!
author: Kristen J.

description:
Cupid bring down your bow!  Let your arrows fly!  Straight to my lovers heart!

Nice attraction!  There always lots people take pictures of it!  In summer months, I seen children try play on it, even I have played on it!  That the bottom part of it!  It looks like a ship from a distance!  On my list of Child Friendly places to visit, read my other reviews, I only visit Child Friendly places!  Hence, in Sacra when hotel say they rather see me spend time with museum go to Sutter (or is it Suter) Fort than an Irish Pub, glad I went to the Fort!  Yes, come to Cupids Span!  Sure take pictures, people do all the time!
author: Karyn C.

description:
Its really not all its cracked up to be. 
OK! Sure it overlooks the water = amazing view.
Yes, its an art structure in the open = playground.
... and yes the structure itself is a bow & arrow = romantic?! I'm not so sure.

If anything, unless you're making your way around from AT&T park to fisherman's wharf on foot (kid less), then its really not worth making a stop off here to fight parking. 
Parking in the area is horrible & if you're lucky enough to find a metered spot be prepared to pay $4.50/hr or find a parking lot/structures that charges $30+ for the day. Yes!! San Francisco is, as I'm sure you were warned, is just THAT expensive, Even as a tourist.
author: Riz B.

description:
Nice public art! I'm a bit confounded on its significance.

And you can touch it!
author: Kislev A.

description:
I don't know what else to say except that it's huge bow and arrow sticking out of the ground. 

I guess it's art. Cool.
author: Jared F.

description:
Super fun, interactive art structure in Embarcadero. If you're just looking at it, there's not too much to do and only so many ooh's and ahh's you can give before you get bored. BUT if you're a little bit adventurous and don't mind possibly getting int a little trouble, take a tip from the kids I saw there and try to run up the arch. :D I promise it's entertaining and fun. You might slip a little, you might not reach the top (I didn't haha, but it's my fault for thinking flats have any grip at all), and you might get a little butt burn sliding back down. I promise though, that it'll be a fun fifteen minutes. :) This is a fun spot to drop by  if you're walking through Embarcadero and the ferry building area. 

There are also a good number of dogs wandering around with their owners, so if you have a dog yourself, get ready to make a few new friends. :)
author: Grace T.

description:
Not much can be said about this.
After all It's just a piece of art.
Nothing truly to critique or service to judge.
I was there when they were erecting it. So at that time I had no idea what was being installed.
As I'm writing this, I'm just no learning about it.

Another great sight along the Embarcadero.
It's not hard to miss. It sticks out pretty well.
The way to really enjoy this is to sit along side it. At the same time you can take in all the great sights along the Embarcadero.
author: John S.

description:
If you can't smile when you see this, ask yourself if you're still alive.

It's a Tony Bennett tribute.  Left his art in SF?


"Your task is not to seek for love, but merely to seek and find all the barriers within yourself that you have built against it."  Rumi
author: Athena S.

description:
I feel like this painted fiberglass beast belongs at Disneyland. 
Kind of a tacky costume jewel on a wealthy world-class city full of artists. I feel like SF could afford better and many local artists could do better, but that's just the armchair opinion of a non-sculptor.
author: Brandon C.

description: Cupids span is one of my favorite art pieces in SF! It is right next to the bay bridge and some great restaurants. Make sure to check it out and leave your heart in SF ;)
author: Vika N.

description:
I like art. Any art. Or  maybe more accurately, anything that is designed to provoke the senses. Toward that end, I think "Cupid's Span", a 2002 sculpture by Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen, fulfills that purpose.

When I first saw the bow and downward-pointed arrow, I immediately thought it was a response to Tony Bennett's "I Left My Heart in San Francisco". I just figured Cupid must be this gargantuan being flying among the Skylab debris out in space trying to shoot arrows at Tony's heart. I don't find it ugly...I just find it amusing much like the Doggie Diner Head out on Sloat. It ain't Michelangelo, but we ain't Florence either.

When the sun beats down on it, you can try lying down where the arrow's shadow falls, though you will be moving like a clock hand to keep up with it. Of course, you also have to worry about fecal matter, whether it's canine or otherwise. Apparently it's good enough for young newlyweds since they have their photos taken there, but I wish people would stop treating it like a climbing apparatus. I think it's pretty shameful how thos hooligans climb it for kicks and deserve a few cracked ribs for their impertinence.

I still think Chicago has the right idea with their big bean in Millennium Park (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/2DfcXGtDv7T_rnvl4lHzaQ?select=Tesh_WSkrUQZrl8L8TI6_Q). It's also a big outdoor art sculpture, but it feels more interactive, and the reflections are cool because it makes for fun-house images of the skyline. I just wish future art pieces in San Francisco could take into account the city's beautiful skyline itself as part of the art. In the meantime, I can't help thinking of this song... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X69xQl-xF1k
author: Ed U.

description: Great spot to take pictures and not too crowded with tourists. Great view of the view bridge and this may be one of my favorite spots in the city now.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I've seen pictures of this place many times and drove through here quite a few but never had the chance to stop by till NOW! I was so excited when we arrived because it's THAT awesome! Well, for me at least. This is a nice piece of artwork I must say, simple but creative. It's just simply amazing! I'd take this and put it outside my backyard if it weren't so big. I think this is one thing they don't have in the souvenir section, which they should!

A lot of people come here for their wedding pictures and I WOULD DO THE SAME when I get married! Besides the cool statue, it's just a nice place to sit, relax...enjoy the view, have a pinic, or take a walk? This is located along the Embarcadero, so Pier 39 is just 3 miles down. They also have restaurants around the block for you to dine in also. If you're lucky enough, you'll find parking along the street for $3/hr.
author: Phung D.

description:
I included this on a walking tour of San Francisco and I love it. We went on a walking tour to try and find and photograph all the San Francisco hearts. 

Great piece of art on the Embarcadero. If you have any one from out of town I would recommend taking them to the ferry building and then the walk to Cupids Span along the water front. Also a great date night walk. Where you can walk and talk. Ahhh I am already so in love.
author: Cris F.

description: So happy that I found this place to check out in SF! It's like the perfect place to do photo-opts for engagement lol! The structure just looks so romantic for some reason. A great place to visit especially during valentines day :).
author: Nhi R.

description: Such a relaxing place! I was in California for 2 weeks vacation. I didn't know this exist until I walk pass it. Very nice place. Great place to relax and enjoy the scenery. A must-see place if you're vacationing in San Francisco. And if you live in SF already, I envy you!
author: Constance A.

description:
In so many ways this piece of public art screams roadside attraction. It's a jumbo-sized bow and arrow aimed at the ground, in the same vein as the world's largest thermometer and a gigantic ball of twine. 

I don't know. Trying to dig up any information on the statue I come up with the same quoted phrase every single Google hit: that the statue "was inspired by San Francisco's reputation as the home port of Eros." 

No further explanations. 

But who calls San Francisco that, though? And why IS it this so-called "home port of Eros"? 

After consulting the artist's website, they reference a myth about Eros/Cupid shooting the earth to make it fertile (another story of which my searches for it are turning up fruitless). 

It's like they offered these semi-poetic answers and we're just supposed to blindly go, "Oooooooh, I get it."

Really this just seems like a joke. Someone made up a couple Eros-related references telling us it's this fine, expensive cloth that only the most sophisticated of us can see. Then they went so far as to make elegant robes of this otherwise invisible cloth, figuratively, by actually constructing "Cupid's Span" and sticking it on the waterfront between the Ferry House and Bay Bridge and keeping it there permanently.  

I'm not saying that public art should always be serious, and that it can't be fun and whimsical, but it's pretty tragic when you've got this expansive, kitschy eyesore out in the open while the Gandhi statue (http://www.yelp.com/biz/gandhi-statue-san-francisco) is being hidden away in a parking lot, donor-related controversy or not.
author: Christine A.

description: Great waterfront grassy area (if the homeless would stop defecating in the swamp grass!!!), usually wet in the morning from sprinklers, but nice in the afternoons.  Beautiful with the Bay Bridge!
author: R J.

description: You thought the waterfront might offer a romantic view of the city, but this abomination intervened with all the subtlety of a sledgehammer to the skull. Cupid's Span is a tacky and unchallenging monstrosity that does not belong in San Francisco, yet here it stands after nearly 15 years. Perhaps the next earthquake will bring an end to this ordeal.
author: B F.

description: if you're artsy than you'll love Cupid's arrow . . . it's super easy to find, me & my roommate just simply walked down the embarcadero from pier 39 (about 20 minutes) & it was a lot of fun taking cool photos with the giant arrow . . .  enough said :)
author: Brooke W.

description:
I find it funny that one of the first monuments tourists see after starting their walk along the embarcadero is the huge bow and arrow jutting out of a small hill.

Despite my usual staying away from that area due to high traffic and horrid rush hour headaches, I did enjoy my walks along the stretch of road on my lunch breaks and during the evenings, a great place to bring my friends visiting from out of town.  

On our last visit, the crew from Friday night skate zoomed in and out of our path with twinkling lights and a boom box that made my friend's experience even more memorable.

Bring a lunch, take a seat on the grass and enjoy sights of the bay on a clear sunny day  : )
author: Miika M.

description: When this was first erected I was shocked to find out that it was "permanent" - it isn't interesting, it isn't meaningful and it's not beautiful.  It's a mockery of the city and the gorgeous bridges and bay behind it.  Come on SF Arts Commission - you can do better than this!
author: Jenn C.

description: How can you not love the view of this state overlooking the bay bridge.  It's also featuring in the book "Larry gets lost in San Francisco" which I give as a gift to friend's children back home after I return from my contract assignments.  Always great to have an actual picture from the place mentioned in the book!
author: Cassandra A.

description:
I love Cupid's Span, I really do. Go ahead and send the hate but the love from the big ass bow already struck me. 

Whenever friends come to visit I begin the tour of San Francisco here, and we always get great views and pictures. 

Call me a sucker or tell me I have shitty taste I don't care. I am a fan of Cupid's Span.

peace, love, and good booze ~ chase
author: Chase S.

description:
Bad Art + Monstrous Size + Prime Location = Public Eyesore.

I have no problem with urban art, pop art, nor with the artist (Oldenburg), but this is over-the-top cheese and lameness.
author: Rick F.

description:
Some folks mock it but it's neat to have something different than some statue or something you see everyday and every place, if they just want dead people posed in stone try the cemetery, LOL.

This park is normally pretty clean, great place to sit and watch the bay and bridge.  Enough out of the way there's normally not a lot of folks here.
author: John F.

description:
hahaha, there's actually a Yelp page for this? :)

It was so much fun reading all the reviews, and see everyone banter about how much they love, hate, or meh about this giant landmark.

Myself personally...I adore this huge bow and arrow! Just goes to show you the eccentricities of San Francisco, as well as the joys of seeing something different for once. The statue is situated around a sort of mini-park along the shore of the bay, so it's nice to sit around, watching people pass by, while sipping on a cup of coffee or catching up with friends.

I came here with my girlfriend (not knowing until know it's name), as we roamed around SF, acting as tourists for the day, before trudging back to our studies at Berkeley.

Fun stuff...great statue...love it! :)
author: Kevin J.

description: Not so much a tourist spot, just a place locals walk around. The view is great, not so much the structure.
author: Catheria S.

description:
Every time i look at the bow & arrow, i say to myself, "what the hell am I looking at?" 
So i look it up, and according to Wikipedia, its supposed to symbolize where Tony Bennett "left his heart" --There's gotta be a better way of doing so.
author: Kyle E.

description:
One of my favorite landmarks in SF.  From the city that gave us Emperor Norton, Gough Street, and the Folsom Street Fair, this is a highly amusing work in a small and well-maintained park with a great view.  I crack up every time I see it, from a boat or the sidewalk.

If you're some old fuddy-duddy--in age or spirit--who thinks all art should be serious and dour, there's plenty of early-20th-century statuary scattered elsewhere in the city.
author: Eric B.

description:
This public art piece at the foot of Folsom Street is just up the block from Gordon Biersch Brewery restaurant, on the Embarcadero.  The piece is just a blast to see. Most people I saw nearby loved it, a few sour pusses did not. 

That's good art. It causes opinions.
author: Drake F.

description: Anything involved with love is a plus with me and Cupid's Span is a major symbol of love! Who doesn't want to be poked by Cupid?!? LoL It is GINORMOUS and very romantic... Standing next to Cupid's Span at The Embarcadero with the view of the bridge, it is perfect for a couple of love birds. =)
author: Anji W.

description: I never knew this existed until one day I saw it on a postcard and said, "This statue is in San Francisco?" So I decided to go find it and it's name and I did. It is a pretty cool statue and piece of artwork. Something that is usually missing in other big cities. I took my date here a few times and it is interesting to see how big it is and great viewpoints when you have the bridge behind it. I have gotten some great pictures of Cupid's Span and I am happy to say, I have been pricked by cupid's arrow.
author: Danster L.

description: I always pass the Cupids Span when I'm on MUNI. From my perspective it looks great. You have the Bay Bridge as the back drop n when it's beautiful n blue it pops right out n looks amazing. I know not everyone likes the Cupid Span but c'mon, not every city has one so be grateful n enjoy the view
author: James P.

description: I hate this thing.  But I respect the fact that I hate it.  Good art should provoke more violent reactions.  And it's OK to make something that not everyone likes:  otherwise the whole world would look like a suburban office park, which would be weaksauce.  So it's important, and OK, and all that.  I still don't *like* it though.
author: Fiid W.

description:
I learned about this landmark from Kwan H.'s pics/review. I had decided to devout my day to visiting SF landmarks so I decided to check out this structure.

Upon arriving, I didn't think it'd be so massive! First off, parking is hard around here. Secondly, it's hard to get a decent shot of the thing (with the Bay bridge in the back ground) with people milling around it...BUT, I do think it's neat, especially the size and the creativity of the bow and arrow in the ground. It's kind of random and I wish there was a placard or something saying more than who funded the art work (the founders of Gap), but I guess art is random and left for multiple interpretations.
author: Janel Y.

description: I'm a fan.  What's not to like?  Adding a few dashes of color and curves against a rather jagged concrete backdrop really makes it wonderful sight to take in.  I just wish the green grass was a little bit more inviting for the common folk as it's usually inhabited by.... feces of different varieties.  I almost have to take a picture every time I walk by it... but none better than the night shot I found online and added to the gallery.
author: Derek K.

description: Cupid's Span is part of my view every day we are at the tiny apartment.  It is so much fun to see how it is used on a daily basis.  Kids play on it, the homeless recline near it, but the very best is when the wedding parties pull up with their photographers.  There is such a sense of joy when these groups make their way around the large piece of public art to get just the right picture.  Then that sense of play carries over and they just have some fun hanging around until it's time to move on.  Thank you, San Francisco, for this great piece.
author: Delaine Z.

description:
I like to come here for lunch.  Other than the obvious bay waters, it's the closest thing to nature around where I work.  Of course, nature doesn't have cupid's arrow, so that makes it more fun.  It makes it seem like I landed in the right place at the right time....or....like I just barely escaped with my life. 

As a tourist, I saw it from afar and wondered "wtf" is that?! It really, really, is an arrow in the ground.  Really.  Still don't know why, but that's probably not the point.

Dog friendly.  Lunch friendly.  Quiet reading time friendly.  I like it that way.
author: cyndi t.

description: 4 stars only b/c I cannot climb on it, but I saw a video of ppl on it.  Otherwise, it's so cute and fun.  Adds a smile on my face.
author: Aubrey D.

description: I love this piece of art structure. It's just so simple and random, like it fell from the sky or a cupid had some bad aiming. I find it rather cute. Having a picnic or reading a book on the grassy area would be pretty awesome. Coming here for a morning jog or an evening date would be nice.
author: Sandy C.

description:
This is my favorite piece of public art along the Embarcadero by far. It may even be my favorite sculpture in SF, period. 

I adore Claes Oldenburg's interpretation of Cupid's mythical bow and arrow of looooooove with this oversized piece. I know it's Oldenburg's schtick to transform everyday items into oversized and colorful pieces, but this sculpture has such a playful sense of humor to it - I always smile when I pass it. 

Even though the bow is stuck in the hillside, it's in action to me....infusing love into downtown SF.
author: Laura G.

description:
MY 200th REVIEW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! i don't know why i chose this place to make my 200th, but i'm on a roll with review san francisco landmarks... so here i gooooooo....

hmm i'm somewhat torn with this rather large piece of art...

the area in which is inhabits, is pretty nice... but you get that view all the way down embarcadero, and now, that horrible epic roasthouse and waterbar now kind of kill the openness of that stretch of the embarcadero, i may have to go with 3 stars instead of 4. 

its something different to look at during my run down the embarcadero. kind of like those random hearts that are around the city like union square, macys, the villas/parkmerced, etc. 

but i definitely would not send a tourist there to take pictures. there are other places in the city i can think of to send people who travel far lengths to come to this city than to some random cupids arrow...
author: Irene C.

description:
Shoot me now.

I'll credit them this: Oldenburg and van Bruggen created a public sculpture that is better in some ways than the originally proposed "giant foot" sculpture. But this absurd bit of hokum is just too lame for me. It neither reflects on the space it resides in, nor the city which it claims as home. The grounds around it, however, are a marvelous spot to stop for a bit in the windy sunshine on a nice day, to have a coffee or lunch or people watch. But egads, folks: this is tackiness taking on new heights! Imagine in 30 years what this behemoth of a slightly shiny pop-art relic will seem in the eyes of passersby.

A bow and arrow with the tip and arch just barely buried underground? Would that the whole damn thing were just a bit deeper. Like, say, completely underground. An open vista out toward the bay would be nice, or maybe a new bench.
author: sascha b.

description:
It's cute. Great use of space and art. I had no idear it had a name. I just thought it was the cute bow and arrow thing in the ground... now I want MORE!



I kinda wish Cupid's Span would work for me :(. (aww emo sob story circa here!)
author: Andrew C.

description: I take short walking breaks from the office out here and it never gets old!  Ingenious complement to the suspension of the Bay Bridge.
author: Norman P.

description: This Disneyland crap makes me want to barf. If only Chicken had been elected mayor, he would have run his pickup truck into this eyesore and San Francisco would have looked like a real city again;
author: H M.

description: The first time I saw this I was like "wtf?" ... But the more I see it, the more I like it. Although it does seem a bit out of place, it's something that every San Franciscan and tourist alike needs to see. Regardless of whether people like it or not, it's there and it's pretty dope. Enjoy it.
author: Brad Y.

description:
UNOFFICAL DOG PARK

This is where many of SoMa's residents go to take their dogs for some play time. There's a large grassy area and the huge obnoxious arrow keeps your dog from running into the street. The grass is also in really good condition--since it isn't officially a dog park. Everyone does a good job at picking up after their dogs. It gets busiest right after work--especially on warm days!

It offers amazing views of the Bay Bridge too.
author: Cindy P.

description:
Interesting landmark, 60 ft. of plastic jutting from the ground to the sky above in the Embarcadero.  It has a fantastic view of the Bay Bridge.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
At least once a week I go here for lunch, either alone or with friends. It's an interesting piece of San Francisco that I hope will be here for a while.

Sometimes I wonder if the bow has landed in San Francisco and that is why we are so full of love in this town. It's just seeping all of the magic from Cupid's bow into our town...seeping...that's a good word...

Regardless, I love the overall size of it. Makes me feel small, which is not usually possible at my height. But I love it and think it's a great piece of art to have around and present to San Franciscans as well as tourists walking along the Embarcadero for their visit.
author: Nicolas H.

description: It's better than the leaking rusty cement intestines in Justin Herman Plaza, but I think the Big Arrow is pretty darn gaudy.  I'll admit I'm not a big modern art fan, but I'd rather see a lovely nude or marine-inspired piece here.  The landscaping is nice, and this is a nice spot for hanging out.  Go at night when the lights of the Bay Bridge are on and you don't have to see all of the primary colors gleaming shinily at you.
author: Andi T.

description:
I call it, "The Death of Love".

oh so emo...
author: Jen I.

description:
I love anything cupid and love related so I love this little landmark out here by my apartment. It made me smile the first time I saw it, just like every time I see a cute little stencil art on the sidewalk. It's unexpected like those random hearts around the city and reminds you how wonderfully random SF people are. I will miss it when I leave SF for sure. 

The only thing to complain about is that they keep putting the fences up and repaving the sidewalk or something around it all the time. Kinda like what they do with Palace of Fine Arts. Also, there is no good angle to take a picture of it and you together..
author: Kwan H.

description: A marginal improvement over the I380 freeway that once stood there.  That monstrosity of a freeway took a 7.0 act of nature to destroy; won't be so lucky this time...
author: Dave J.

description: God damn you Cupid, how can you miss me with this big ass Love bow of yours? You know I need your help, disgustingly strong drinks down in a shitty TL bar just don't get me nothing no mo! I too want to say I left my heart in SF, so come on, aim again!  I'm not hard to miss, im the drunk chick tumbling home alone on a saturday night with a grey cloud over my head and mascara all over my face. So please, can you make sure i wake up so fresh so clean with The charming prince next to me? I promised you'll still be my favorite naked man!
author: Margie B.

description: So it fell from the sky?  I just like looking at it from the N Judah.
author: John F.

description: This thing is awful.  I do not understand putting up a piece of 'art' that looks like it should be at Disneyland's California Adventure, smack-dab in the middle of an already amazing view.  Everytime I go by it it pisses me off.  Leave the Bay view alone to it's own devices.
author: e w.

description: I guess it's cool.  But it's not that cool.  The Free Stamp in Cleveland is much cooler.  So are the spidery thingies walking out of the bay right here in San Francisco.
author: John S.

description: Ugh. Really? It's hideous and tacky. It belongs in Cleveland, not San Francisco.
author: Matt L.

description:
i have two simple assertions. it's pretty and i like it.

so much for those four wasted years of art theory and criticism.
author: shannon e t.

description: Fabulous art installation situated by the San Francisco waterfront. I love taking my dogs for a run here after rollerblading with them from the ballpark. Definitely a nice stop to take a moment and say "I FLOVE SAN FRANCISCO!"
author: Miles G.

description:
i actually think this piece of art is very fitting to san francisco.  
it's cute
romantic
unique
it always cheers me up when i pass by it... as well as the hearts in san francisco... :)
author: charlotte s.

description: I have admired this statue for some time...... I was this past warm Sunday that I fully appreciated it's purpose.  The park itself is great for relaxing, people watching, great views of the Bay Bridge, Ferry building, and awesome boats on the water.  If you take someone special there cupid's bow just might strike you!
author: Alli F.

description: This place was a nice place to eat our taco truck burrito and tacos....this was cute...the start of our day of site seeing.....
author: Sheryll D.

description: Gotta love Claes Oldenburg -- mmm more public art...
author: Leo C.

description: My husband and I are SF Natives and actually chose this site to get married at with the bridge as a backdrop. Needless to say IT WAS A GORGEOUS wedding and enjoyed by all including tourists! Love it!
author: Shawn T.

description: Ugh! Really? More everyday objects writ large? This time with a pun?! I think I would have had more sympathy for the "everyday object" line of thought if it were realized in the form of a gigantic used condom. Something you actually do see everyday.
author: H G.

description: It's alright.  Despite the complaints about this statue, at least it's not as scary as the weird metal sculpture people things that are just down the Embarcadero.  Those things are just odd.
author: Dianne d.

description: Awwww or ehhhhh? Do I Love it or do I hate it? Is a marvelous idea or a waste of money and space? When taking the N down to the ball park (well now it the T) I like looking out the train window and seeing this bow and arrow. I think I've got used to seeing it and now I like it unlike some of the crazy sculpture in San Francisco Whoo.
author: Kristina S.

description:
the bow and arrow piece is somewhat better than those two metal people sculptures at pier 14.

i like to talk to the homeless people sitting on the mound. they have such great stories.

rating: two paper towels.
author: dave tastic fantasmo x.

description: I just like it. Walking along the embarc, checking out the bridge, ol TI and lo and behold this ginormous bow and arrow. just awesome.
author: Aleks G.
